summary: The video explores various judo techniques that are old, lost, or forgotten, providing a historical context and demonstration of each technique.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a black and white scene of two individuals dressed in traditional martial arts uniforms, standing in a dimly lit area. They face each other, with a group of onlookers in similar attire seated in the background. The two individuals engage in a martial arts demonstration, showcasing a series of moves that include grappling and throwing techniques. The onlookers observe attentively as the demonstration unfolds. The video concludes with Japanese text on the screen, which reads "消えた技 忘れられた技法" (Shinai waza, wasurerareta jutsu), translating to "Lost techniques, forgotten methods," indicating a focus on traditional martial arts skills that may have been lost or forgotten over time.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing himself and the topic of discussion: old, lost, and forgotten techniques, specifically mentioning those released by the Kodokan. His tone is informative and slightly enthusiastic. He indicates that the content will be linked in the description and summarizes that the techniques are either new or variations of existing ones, potentially impactful in competition. He then states the title, referring to lost and forgotten techniques in Japanese.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen displaying Japanese text in white characters, which translates to "Lost Techniques, Forgotten Methods." The scene then transitions to a black-and-white photograph of two individuals practicing martial arts. The person on the left, wearing a dark top and white pants, is executing a technique on the person on the right, who is dressed in a white top and dark pants. The background features a wooden wall, and the photograph has a vintage appearance, suggesting it is from an earlier time. The video maintains this image for several frames, emphasizing the martial arts technique being demonstrated.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker introducing and describing a judo technique, Seoi Otoshi, mentioning its appearance in a 1928 photo. He adopts a descriptive, informative tone, focusing on arm hooking, waist-grabbing, and the cutting-down motion involved in the throw. He clarifies that it's not a back lift, but there is back loading. The description details the use of the sleeve grip and belt grip.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white photograph of two individuals practicing a martial arts technique, dressed in traditional attire with white pants and dark tops, against a wooden backdrop. The scene transitions to a modern setting where two individuals in white martial arts uniforms, one with a black belt and the other with a red belt, demonstrate the technique "Seoi-otoshi" (a throw) against a blue background. The text "Seoi-otoshi" appears on the screen, indicating the name of the move being performed. The video showcases the execution of the technique, with the person in the red belt successfully throwing the person in the black belt to the ground. The demonstration is repeated, emphasizing the technique's steps and movements. The video concludes with the person in the red belt standing and preparing for another demonstration, highlighting the instructional nature of the content. The logos of "IJF Academy" and "Kodokan" are visible in the background, indicating the affiliation with international judo organizations.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker, discussing the use of grip to assist the arm and timing in combat, with a tone suggesting instruction or analysis. He describes techniques, mentioning "cutting on the lapel and the arm," "sudden explosiveness," and techniques like "Sae Otoshi." He transitions to discussing different variations of the move, such as "standing" versus "kneeling down." Towards the end, he emphasizes the potential benefits of adding it to one's arsenal.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a black and white illustration of two sumo wrestlers engaged in a match. The wrestler on the left is in a dominant position, with his legs wrapped around the opponent's waist, while the wrestler on the right is on his back, seemingly in the process of being thrown. Both wrestlers are wearing traditional sumo attire, including mawashi (sumo belts). The illustration is detailed, capturing the dynamic movement and tension of the moment. Below the image, there is Japanese text that reads "第6回 約束" (Dai 6-kai Yakusoku), which translates to "The 6th Promise," followed by "有馬興四郎" (Yuma Keizaburō), likely the name of the artist or the subject of the illustration. The text also includes "昭和38年" (Showa 38-nen), indicating the year 1963 in the Japanese calendar. The background is plain white, emphasizing the illustration and the text. The video remains static, focusing solely on the illustration and its details.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker who says "Suri Otoshi".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white illustration of two individuals engaged in a martial arts move, possibly judo, with one person executing a throw on the other. The illustration is detailed, showing the dynamic motion and technique involved in the move. Below the illustration, there is Japanese text that reads "有馬純四段" (Yamada Jun, 4th Dan) and "通谷道場" (Tōgatōjō), indicating the name of the practitioner and the dojo. The year "明治38年" (Meiji 38, 1885) is also mentioned, providing historical context. The scene then transitions to a live-action demonstration of the same martial arts move, performed by two individuals in traditional martial arts attire. The person executing the throw is wearing a white gi with a black belt, while the other individual is dressed in a white gi with a black hakama. The background is plain and dark, focusing attention on the practitioners and their movements. The video captures the fluidity and precision of the martial arts technique, emphasizing the connection between the illustrated technique and its real-life application.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a speaker noting something is "interesting". The speaker continues, explaining an article mentions that a particular technique was supposed to replace another, but was later replaced itself. The speaker refers to a throw, which they describe as a "sacrificing throw", and indicates they will show what it looks like. They mention that Sumi Gaeshi is technically a more efficient throw, going on to describe the technique further, including how the practitioner pushes their opponent towards a corner and then goes to their side and throws them forward. The speaker compares it to Yokowakare, but notes the differences, including the way the opponent is thrown to the back. The speaker states they will show Yokowakare later.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white illustration of a person in traditional Japanese attire, performing a bowing gesture with one hand on their knee and the other hand touching their head. The illustration is accompanied by Japanese text at the bottom, which translates to "Japanese Encyclopedia, Meiji 43 Year." The scene then transitions to a modern setting where two individuals in white judo uniforms are practicing a technique. The person on the left wears a black belt, while the person on the right wears a red belt. They are engaged in a judo move called "Yoko-wakare," as indicated by the text on the screen. The background is a solid blue color, and the logos of the "UFC Academy" and "Budweiser" are visible in the top corners. The video captures the dynamic movement of the judo practitioners as they execute the technique, with the focus on their lower bodies and the interaction between their legs and feet.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip consists of one male speaker discussing a martial arts technique called "O-Yoko-Wakare", mentioning foot sweeps and arm movements in a descriptive, instructional tone. He also makes references to "Yoko-Gake" and its variations. Throughout the explanation, the speaker maintains a steady, conversational pace.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two individuals in white judo uniforms practicing a technique on a blue mat, with one person lying on the ground and the other standing over them, holding their arm. The text "Yoko-wakare" appears on the screen, indicating the name of the technique being demonstrated. The scene transitions to a competitive judo match where two athletes, one in a blue uniform and the other in white, grapple on a yellow mat, with a referee in a suit observing closely. The background features a crowd of spectators and a banner with the Suzuki logo. The video then shifts to another judo match between two competitors in white uniforms, one with a red belt and the other with a white belt, engaged in a dynamic exchange on a red mat, with a scoreboard and more spectators in the background. The scene transitions to a black-and-white photograph of two judo practitioners in traditional attire, locked in a grappling position, with Japanese text at the bottom of the image. The text reads "第8回 棋分" (The 8th Judogi Match) and "横綱一役 [柔道手] 明治42年" (The Great Kisen [Judo Practitioner] Meiji 42), indicating the historical context of the photograph. The video concludes with a close-up of the same black-and-white photograph, emphasizing the traditional attire and the grappling technique, with the Japanese text remaining visible at the bottom.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing a Judo competition example, mentioning techniques such as "Mongolian Judoka" and "flattening herself to the side". The speaker's tone is analytical and descriptive. The audio then moves to a brief discussion of Yokowakare, comparing it to Yokogake, where the speaker describes gripping and foot sweeping techniques. Finally, the speaker emphasizes the differences between Yokowakare and other techniques and explains a side-blocking foot sweeping motion.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white photograph of two individuals engaged in a martial arts practice, wearing traditional white uniforms with black belts. The text in Japanese at the bottom of the image reads "Nage-no-kata" (投げの型), which translates to "Throwing Kata," indicating a specific form or pattern of throws in martial arts. The scene transitions to a modern-day demonstration of the same technique by two individuals in a dojo setting, wearing white martial arts uniforms with black belts. The background is a plain blue wall, and the floor is a light-colored mat. The text "Nage-no-kata" appears at the top of the screen, reinforcing the focus on the throwing technique. The video then shows a close-up of the feet of the individuals, highlighting their precise footwork and positioning as they execute the throw. The demonstration continues with the two individuals performing the throw, with one person lifting and flipping the other to the ground. The sequence captures the fluid motion and technique involved in the throw, emphasizing the skill and coordination required. The video concludes with the individuals lying on the mat, having completed the throw, and then transitioning to a standing position, ready to repeat the technique. The consistent background and attire throughout the video maintain a focused and instructional atmosphere, highlighting the traditional and modern aspects of martial arts practice.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker discussing "yoko gake," a martial arts technique, describing its execution and variations, including "o yoko wakare." His tone is instructional and descriptive.  He notes the reduced arm work in the basic form, emphasizing ankle slapping and pushing the sleeve to the side, contrasting it with a more forceful pull. He also describes its randori application and possible variations, indicating it might look like "sasae". The speaker suggests this move can go to the side with over and under hooks, easy to perform with nogi.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a black and white photograph of two individuals engaged in a martial arts move, possibly judo, on a grassy field. One person is on the ground, bent over with their head down, while the other is standing over them, holding onto their uniform. Both are wearing traditional martial arts attire. The background is a simple grassy area, and there is Japanese text at the bottom of the image, which translates to "Chapter 2: Judo, Small Fry, 1944." The scene remains static throughout the video, with no changes in the individuals' positions or the environment.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker is discussing a debated technique, specifically knee on belly in Judo. He refers to a 1929 picture by Oda Tsunetane that shows a knee on the solar plexus. Another example of the technique is presented from a different angle. The speaker's tone is informative and explanatory.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white photograph of two individuals practicing judo. One person is lying on the ground while the other is standing over them, seemingly demonstrating a technique. The background is plain, and there is Japanese text at the bottom of the image, which translates to "Judo practice, 1924, Tokyo." The scene then transitions to a modern-day judo practice session, where two individuals in white judo uniforms are engaged in a grappling position on a green mat. The person on top is applying a technique called "Uki-gatame," as indicated by the text in the bottom left corner. The logos of the Kodokan and the International Judo Federation Academy are visible in the top corners of the frame, signifying the official nature of the training. The video showcases the evolution of judo techniques from historical practice to contemporary training.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by introducing "Uki Gatame," mentioning its present-day variation similar to an "S-mount" in Jiu-Jitsu. He explains that the basic form, if executed with a crossface, will lead to almost immediate tapping due to its potential as a strangle, especially when combined with pulling the sleeves and digging down at the knee and solar plexus. He concludes by stating that this technique is known as Uki Gatame today.

events_list.video_caption: The video features two individuals practicing judo techniques on a tatami mat. Both are dressed in traditional white judo uniforms, with one wearing a black belt and the other a red belt. They are engaged in a grappling position, with the black belt individual on the ground and the red belt person applying a hold. The text "Uki-gatame" appears on the screen, indicating the name of the technique being demonstrated. The background is plain, with a logo in the top left corner and the text "IJF Academy" in the top right corner, suggesting an instructional setting. The scene transitions to a black-and-white historical clip showing a similar judo technique being performed in a dimly lit environment, with several onlookers in the background. The video emphasizes the continuity of judo techniques across different eras and settings.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing a move in Jujutsu, referencing an "arm bar" and describing transitions into "S mount" and "neon belly" positions, using an analytical and informative tone. The speaker elaborates on the sensation associated with neon belly, saying they "feel like they're almost like they're hovering or floating."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a group of individuals dressed in traditional martial arts uniforms, known as gi, engaging in a series of judo techniques. The setting appears to be a dojo or training hall, with a dark background and a mat on the floor. The participants are seen performing various throws and grappling maneuvers, demonstrating their skills and techniques. The focus is on the fluidity and precision of their movements, with some individuals standing and others kneeling in the background, observing the demonstration. The atmosphere is one of discipline and concentration, as the practitioners showcase their mastery of judo. The video captures the essence of martial arts training, emphasizing the importance of technique, control, and respect for the art form.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features one male speaker, who suggests listeners leave additional comments and explore a link to a "Kodokan article," mentioning that it includes information about the All Japan Competition. He encourages the audience to "take your time and read it" and "enjoy the pictures" before signing off. The tone is conversational and informative.
